content.objective: Create HTML5 index.html with valid document structure, blue background (#0000FF), centered white 'Hello World!' text, responsive viewport configuration, and WCAG 2.1 AA accessibility compliance
success_criteria: Valid HTML5 document structure passes W3C validator with zero errors
Blue background (#0000FF) with white text (#FFFFFF) achieves minimum 8.59:1 contrast ratio (exceeds WCAG AA 4.5:1 requirement)
Text 'Hello World!' is centered both horizontally and vertically using CSS Flexbox
Responsive viewport meta tag enables proper rendering on mobile (320px), tablet (768px), and desktop (1920px+) viewports
Page is fully self-contained with no external dependencies (CSS, JS, images, fonts)

validation_tests.expected_result: Zero errors, zero warnings from validator.w3.org

validation_tests.description: WCAG 2.1 AA accessibility audit using axe-core
validation_tests.expected_result: Zero violations for color contrast, semantic HTML, lang attribute, and ARIA compliance
Text remains centered and readable at 320px, 768px, and 1920px widths
Consistent rendering in Chrome, Firefox, Safari, and Edge (latest stable versions)
Page loads successfully via file:// protocol with no external resource requests

content.notes: Implementation uses <style> tag in <head> for CSS (not inline styles) to maintain separation of concerns while meeting no-external-dependencies requirement. CSS Flexbox preferred over Grid for single-element centering due to broader browser support and simplicity. Blue shade #0000FF (pure blue) provides maximum contrast (8.59:1) and eliminates ambiguity. HTML structure is minimal (DOCTYPE, html, head, body) without semantic elements (header, main, footer) to maintain atomic simplicity for test page. Page title set to 'Hello World' for HTML5 compliance and accessibility.

content.objective: Execute automated validation suite covering HTML5 compliance, WCAG 2.1 AA accessibility standards, responsive design behavior, and cross-browser compatibility
success_criteria: W3C HTML5 validator returns zero errors and zero warnings
axe-core accessibility audit passes with zero violations for WCAG 2.1 AA standards
Visual regression tests confirm blue background and white centered text render correctly across all target viewports
Cross-browser tests pass in Chrome, Firefox, Safari, and Edge (latest stable versions)
All validation tests complete in under 60 seconds total execution time

validation_tests.description: Automated HTML5 validation via W3C validator API
validation_tests.expected_result: HTTP 200 response with validation.messages array empty

validation_tests.description: Automated accessibility audit via axe-core programmatic API
validation_tests.expected_result: violations array empty, passes array contains color-contrast, html-has-lang, document-title rules
Text remains centered within 5px tolerance, background fills entire viewport
Page loads successfully, computed background-color is rgb(0, 0, 255), text color is rgb(255, 255, 255)
Performance score ≥95, Accessibility score 100, Best Practices score ≥95

content.notes: Test suite integrates W3C validator, axe-core, Selenium WebDriver, and Lighthouse. Tests run in CI/CD pipeline as quality gate before deployment. Visual regression tests use headless Chrome for deterministic screenshot comparison. Cross-browser tests target latest stable versions only (no IE11 or legacy browser support required per requirements analysis). All tests must be idempotent and produce deterministic results.

content.objective: Conduct manual accessibility review to validate WCAG 2.1 AA compliance for nuanced concerns not covered by automated tools, including keyboard navigation, screen reader compatibility, and contextual accessibility
success_criteria: Keyboard navigation test confirms no interactive elements require keyboard access (static page)
Screen reader test (NVDA/JAWS) announces page title 'Hello World' and text content correctly
Color contrast manual verification confirms white-on-blue meets WCAG AA standards using contrast checker tool
Manual review confirms semantic HTML structure is appropriate for content (no unnecessary ARIA attributes)
Accessibility review documentation completed with zero critical or high-severity issues

validation_tests.description: Screen reader compatibility test with NVDA
validation_tests.expected_result: NVDA announces 'Hello World, document' with correct language context

validation_tests.description: Manual color contrast verification using WebAIM contrast checker
validation_tests.expected_result: Contrast ratio displays as 8.59:1, passes WCAG AA and AAA for normal text
No tab stops present (static page with no interactive elements), no keyboard traps
HTML structure is minimal and appropriate, no unnecessary ARIA attributes, lang attribute present

content.notes: Manual accessibility review complements automated testing to catch nuanced issues. Given the simplicity of this static page (no interactive elements, no navigation), manual review focuses on screen reader compatibility and color contrast verification. Review uses NVDA on Windows and VoiceOver on macOS for cross-platform validation. Documentation includes screenshots of contrast checker results and screen reader output for audit trail.

content.objective: Review static HTML page for security best practices and recommend optional security headers for deployment configuration (CSP, X-Content-Type-Options, X-Frame-Options, Referrer-Policy)
success_criteria: Security review confirms no inline JavaScript or external resource dependencies that could introduce XSS vectors
Recommended Content Security Policy documented for deployment: default-src 'none'; style-src 'unsafe-inline'; base-uri 'self'; form-action 'none'
Additional security headers documented: X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff, X-Frame-Options: DENY, Referrer-Policy: no-referrer
Security review documentation confirms page is safe for deployment in any environment (local file system, web server, CDN)
No security vulnerabilities identified in static HTML content

validation_tests.expected_result: Zero inline JavaScript, zero external script references, zero event handlers
Recommended CSP policy allows only inline styles, blocks all other resource types
Documentation includes deployment instructions for Apache, Nginx, and static hosting platforms

content.notes: Security review focuses on defense-in-depth principles even for simple static content. While the HTML file itself requires no modifications, security headers should be configured at deployment layer (web server or hosting platform). CSP policy is restrictive by default, allowing only inline styles required for the page. Security headers are optional for local file system deployment but recommended for web server deployment. Documentation includes configuration examples for common deployment targets.

content.objective: Create minimal deployment documentation covering usage instructions, browser compatibility notes, accessibility compliance summary, and optional security header configuration
success_criteria: README.md documents deployment instructions for local file system, web server, and static hosting platforms
Browser compatibility matrix documents tested browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge) and viewport sizes (320px, 768px, 1920px)
Accessibility compliance summary confirms WCAG 2.1 AA compliance with contrast ratio documentation
Optional security headers section provides configuration examples for Apache and Nginx
Documentation is concise (under 500 words) and follows Markdown best practices

validation_tests.expected_result: README.md passes markdownlint with zero errors
All required sections present: Usage, Browser Compatibility, Accessibility, Security Headers
All technical details match implementation (color codes, contrast ratios, browser versions)

content.notes: Documentation is optional per requirements analysis but recommended for completeness. README.md is minimal and focuses on deployment instructions and technical specifications. Documentation does not duplicate information available in code comments or validation test results. Security headers section is clearly marked as optional and deployment-specific. Browser compatibility matrix uses standard format for easy reference.
